abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Irrigation
            Modernization Project for Mexico were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: modernization of irrigation
            infrastructure and on-farm technology improvements is a
            necessary but not sufficient condition to increase
            competitiveness in irrigated agriculture. Irrigation
            improvement interventions need to be accompanied by actions
            that support farmers and producers, particularly the small
            ones, in the areas of organization, financial management and
            commercialization. Modernization of irrigation projects,
            particularly within the DR a (Irrigation Districts or
            Distritos de Riego) and UR (Irrigation Units or Unidades de
            Riego) located in over-exploited aquifers and/or
            over-allocated surface water resources, should be done
            within an integral water resources management framework,
            where the water balance, the availability of the resource,
            and other users including environmental water needs are
            taken into account. Particularly crucial for the
            optimization of benefits that could be derived from
            water-saving technologies is the provision of technical
            assistance to farmers as a complement to the on-farm
            investments for at least the first agriculture-year. Since
            the project appears to have benefited the already better-off
            farmers and/or agricultural producers, the greater project
            absorption by small farmers and producers will require
            special targeting mechanisms, implicit eligibility criteria
            and special financial terms to participate. Since irrigation
            modernization and technological improvements are
            medium-term, it is necessary to ensure that these programs
            and multiannual, so unnecessary delays are avoided.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project's main objective is to
            assist the Government of Mexico in its efforts to adopt a
            new model to improve the competitiveness of irrigated
            agriculture and the efficiency of irrigation water use, in
            both Irrigation Districts (Distritos de Riego, DR) and
            Irrigation Units (Unidudes de Riego, UR), that would include
            the development of partnerships between the public and
            private sectors as well as effective institutional
            collaboration within the public sector, plus the
            strengthening of a demand-driven approach to investment
            decisions and financing. The project has the following four
            components: Component 1) will finance demand-driven
            investment sub-projects aimed at improving the efficiency of
            water distribution to rehabilitate and modernize irrigation
            infrastructure as well as to improve conservation and
            maintenance machinery and equipment within the framework of
            IIIPs. Component 2) will support demand-driven investments
            subprojects prepared by water users in irrigation districts
            (DR) and irrigation units (UR), within the framework of
            IIIPs, and presented to their respective local project
            authorities for financing. Under this component, the
            project, through CNA will provide technical and financial
            assistance to beneficiaries to improve on-farm irrigation
            systems and water use efficiency, but at the same time,
            through an agreement with SAGARPA, project beneficiaries
            would receive financial support and technical assistance
            from the ongoing government program Alianza Contigo to
            increase agricultural productivity, diversify production and
            improve their marketing capabilities. Component 3) the
            objective is to strengthen water users' associations
            and improve their technical, managerial and financial
            capabilities to administer and operate their respective
            irrigation systems as well as participate in the decision
            making process regarding Integrated Irrigation Modernization
            Project (PMIR) investment financing. Component 4) A Project
            Coordinating System (PCS) will be established within
            National Water Commission (CNA's) General Irrigation
            Infrastructure Sub-Division (Subdireccion General de
            Infraestructura Hidroagricola, SGIH). Its main
            responsibilities will be the coordination of the activities
            that will be executed under the project, monitoring and
            evaluation, carrying out of audits, supervise the
            preparation of the Integrated Investment Plans, and the
            preparation of the Annual Operating Plans and the periodic
            reports to the Bank on project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Irrigation and Drainage
            Modernization Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) is
            based on Mexico's environmental laws and regulations,
            and on the Bank's environment operational directive,
            specifically its safeguards on pollution control, natural
            habitat protection, adequate pest management, dam security,
            cultural heritage preservation, and, the protection of
            international waters. The EA analyzes the institutional
            capacity of the National Water Commission (NWC), the
            country's hydrological aspects, issues regarding the
            over-exploitation of aquifers, including the location of
            irrigation districts and any potential environmental
            adversity in relation to natural protected areas, with a
            view on how the implementation of the Irrigation and
            Drainage Modernization Project might impact the environment.
            The eligible irrigation and drainage project works will be
            classified per three group types: 1) those works where
            irrigation water supply sources derive from aquifers,
            classified as critical due to its over-exploitation, or
            salinity content. In this case, the regional master plan
            regulations should apply, to comply with set environmental
            guidelines, and, in addition, a hydrology balance test will
            be conducted to assess any environmental adversity on the
            aquifers; 2) those works where the source for irrigation
            derives from surface waters, likely to be related to
            non-critical aquifers, in which case the NWC should
            appropriately justify the reasons for eligibility; and, 3)
            those works where irrigation sources derive from surface
            waters, but non-related to critical aquifers, in which case
            the Bank shall apply its operational requirements, and the
            NWC comply with the country's current environmental
            legal framework.
